G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, existing custody and parenting‑time orders may be modified when there has been a material and substantial change in circumstances and the proposed modification is in the child’s best interests.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, existing custody and parenting‑time orders may be modified when there has been a material and substantial change in circumstances and the proposed modification is in the child’s best interests.

Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).proposition: Under Massachusetts law, existing custody and parenting‑time orders may be modified when there has been a material and substantial change in circumstances and the proposed modification is in the child’s best interests.
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).support_reasoning: This concurring opinion is about relocation and the statutory framework for custody and visitation under the paternity statute, not about the standard for modifying existing custody and parenting‑time orders. It does not discuss the requirement of a material and substantial change in circumstances as a predicate for modification, nor does it articulate a two‑part ‘change of circumstances plus best interests’ test. The proposition describes a general Massachusetts modification standard that is not addressed or decided in this case.
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).relevant_excerpt: After paternity was established, the judge was obligated to take as a given that the mother and the child resided 400 miles apart from, and in another State than, the father, and to fashion custody and visitation orders pursuant to the three factors set out in G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), again respecting and not disturbing the mother’s decision to relocate.

The Court has continuing jurisdiction ov.raw_text: The Court has continuing jurisdiction over the parties and over the custody and parenting time orders at issue pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, G.L. c. 209C, § 20, G.L. c. 215, § 6, and the prior Judgment of this Court.
The Court has continuing jurisdiction ov.proposition: This Court has continuing jurisdiction over the parties and over the custody and parenting time orders at issue pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, G.L. c. 209C, § 20, G.L. c. 215, § 6, and the prior Judgment of this Court.

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 6.proposition: This Court has continuing jurisdiction over the parties and over the custody and parenting time orders at issue pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, G.L. c. 209C, § 20, G.L. c. 215, § 6, and the prior Judgment of this Court.

The paramount consideration in any modif.raw_text: The paramount consideration in any modification of custody or parenting time is the best interests of the child.
The paramount consideration in any modif.proposition: The paramount consideration in any modification of custody or parenting time is the best interests of the child.

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 840\u201.proposition: The paramount consideration in any modification of custody or parenting time is the best interests of the child.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 840\u201.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely reiterates that in custody determinations the best interests of the child are the paramount concern, citing prior Massachusetts precedent. Although the case is not itself a postjudgment modification proceeding, it treats the best-interests standard as the governing, overriding principle in custody and visitation matters generally, which is consistent with using it to describe the paramount consideration in any change to custody or parenting time.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 840\u201.relevant_excerpt: “In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry of what is ‘best for the child’ is firmly rooted in American history… The ‘best interests’ standard appeared in our case law at least as early as 1865… It has been adhered to ever since. See, e.g., … Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 710 (1985) (‘best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern’); … DeFerrari v. DeFerrari, 220 Mass. 38, 41 (1914) (custody award is subject to revision ‘as the best interests of the child may demand’).”

Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406 (1976).proposition: The paramount consideration in any modification of custody or parenting time is the best interests of the child.
Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406 (1976).support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states that in custody determinations, the governing principle and dominating rule is the welfare of the child, and that the child’s happiness and welfare are the controlling consideration. Although the case is not about modification post-divorce under a particular statute, it addresses allocation and adjustment of custody/visitation and clearly affirms that the child’s best interests are paramount in such determinations, which is materially the same principle as in later modification proceedings.
Vilakazi v. Maxie, 371 Mass. 406 (1976).relevant_excerpt: “In Hersey v. Hersey, 271 Mass. 545, 555 (1930), we stated the basic rule applicable in such cases as follows: ‘The governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child. That is so both as matter of law and as matter of humanity. Every public and private consideration establishes this as the dominating rule.’ We repeated that same language in Jenkins v. Jenkins, 304 Mass. 248, 250 (1939), and added: ‘…the happiness and the welfare of the child should be the controlling consideration.’”

A pattern of parental conduct that under.raw_text: A pattern of parental conduct that undermines a child’s education, including chronic unexcused absences and failure to support educational services, can constitute a material and substantial change in circumstances justifying modification of custody or legal‑decision‑making authority, because such conduct directly affects the child’s welfare.
A pattern of parental conduct that under.proposition: A pattern of parental conduct that undermines a child’s education, including chronic unexcused absences and failure to support educational services, can constitute a material and substantial change in circumstances justifying modification of custody or legal‑decision‑making authority, because such conduct directly affects the child’s welfare.

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.raw_text: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 404–05 (1981)
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.proposition: A pattern of parental conduct that undermines a child’s education, including chronic unexcused absences and failure to support educational services, can constitute a material and substantial change in circumstances justifying modification of custody or legal‑decision‑making authority, because such conduct directly affects the child’s welfare.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.support_reasoning: The case is a direct appeal from an initial divorce/custody judgment, not a proceeding to modify an existing custody or legal‑decision‑making order based on a material and substantial change in circumstances. The opinion does not discuss parental conduct undermining a child’s education, chronic absences, or failure to support educational services, nor does it set out any rule that such a pattern would justify modification. Its custody analysis focuses on best interests, parental conflict, and feasibility of joint custody, not on educational neglect or standards for modification of prior orders.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.relevant_excerpt: “Although the husband had had involvement with the child rearing functions and responsibilities, the judge concluded that because the parties have basic fundamental differences in the major areas of child rearing, such as health care, religion and education, as well as in day-to-day decision making and philosophy of discipline, an order providing joint custody would run contrary to the children’s happiness and welfare. That determination has ample support in the record.”

Diaz v. Diaz, 45 Mass. App. Ct. 504, 506.raw_text: Diaz v. Diaz, 45 Mass. App. Ct. 504, 506–07 (1998)
Diaz v. Diaz, 45 Mass. App. Ct. 504, 506.proposition: A pattern of parental conduct that undermines a child’s education, including chronic unexcused absences and failure to support educational services, can constitute a material and substantial change in circumstances justifying modification of custody or legal‑decision‑making authority, because such conduct directly affects the child’s welfare.
Diaz v. Diaz, 45 Mass. App. Ct. 504, 506.case_name: Reproductive Rights Network v. President of the University of Massachusetts
Diaz v. Diaz, 45 Mass. App. Ct. 504, 506.support_reasoning: The opinion is not Diaz v. Diaz and does not concern custody, parental conduct, or the child’s education. It addresses First Amendment and Massachusetts Civil Rights Act issues involving university facilities and political speech. Nothing in the holding or reasoning discusses material and substantial changes in circumstances for custody modification based on interference with a child’s education, so it cannot support the stated proposition.
Diaz v. Diaz, 45 Mass. App. Ct. 504, 506.relevant_excerpt:
The issues are not moot as a result of the University’s attempt to formalize existing rules.

2. The University’s defenses. In their cross appeal, the defendants advance two arguments. The first is that the decision to close the University was based on reasonable security considerations. The second is that the meetings were not protected speech because the plaintiffs allegedly conspired to commit an illegal act.

Where parents with joint legal custody a.raw_text: Where parents with joint legal custody are unable to cooperate or make shared decisions on critical issues such as education, the Court may modify the allocation of legal‑custody authority, including by granting one parent final decision‑making power on specific issues, when doing so is in the child’s best interests.
Where parents with joint legal custody a.proposition: Where parents with joint legal custody are unable to cooperate or make shared decisions on critical issues such as education, the Court may modify the allocation of legal‑custody authority, including by granting one parent final decision‑making power on specific issues, when doing so is in the child’s best interests.

Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. at 547\u201.proposition: Where parents with joint legal custody are unable to cooperate or make shared decisions on critical issues such as education, the Court may modify the allocation of legal‑custody authority, including by granting one parent final decision‑making power on specific issues, when doing so is in the child’s best interests.

Abbott v. Virusso, 68 Mass. App. Ct. 326.raw_text: Abbott v. Virusso, 68 Mass. App. Ct. 326, 330–33 (2007)
Abbott v. Virusso, 68 Mass. App. Ct. 326.proposition: Where parents with joint legal custody are unable to cooperate or make shared decisions on critical issues such as education, the Court may modify the allocation of legal‑custody authority, including by granting one parent final decision‑making power on specific issues, when doing so is in the child’s best interests.
Abbott v. Virusso, 68 Mass. App. Ct. 326.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns a removal/relocation dispute where the mother had primary physical custody and the parents had joint legal custody, but the court does not discuss modifying legal custody, reallocating decision‑making authority, or granting one parent final say on issues like education. The analysis focuses on the Yannas ‘real advantage’ removal standard, best‑interests findings, and procedural issues with in‑camera child interviews, not on altering joint legal custody because of parental inability to cooperate. Accordingly, it does not provide authority for modifying legal custody or assigning final decision‑making power on specific issues.
Abbott v. Virusso, 68 Mass. App. Ct. 326.relevant_excerpt: In cases such as the one before us, the “real advantage” test applies. See Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 705, 706, 711 (1985) (parents had “joint legal custody,” but mother had “physical custody”). ... Under the real advantage test, “[s]hould it be found that there is a genuine, recognizable advantage to the custodial parent from the move, the inquiry then turns to whether the move is consistent with the children’s best interests.”

The Court has broad discretion to adjust.raw_text: The Court has broad discretion to adjust parenting‑time schedules, including weekday and school‑night overnights, to protect a child’s educational needs and stability.
The Court has broad discretion to adjust.proposition: The Court has broad discretion to adjust parenting‑time schedules, including weekday and school‑night overnights, to protect a child’s educational needs and stability.

Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182, 191.proposition: The Court has broad discretion to adjust parenting‑time schedules, including weekday and school‑night overnights, to protect a child’s educational needs and stability.
Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182, 191.support_reasoning: The opinion does not discuss parenting‑time schedules, weekday or school‑night overnights, or educational‑stability–based adjustments to parenting time. Its substantive family-law holdings concern (1) credits for Social Security disability dependency benefits, (2) the judge’s authority to attach assets to secure support and college expenses, and (3) standards for modifying legal custody. While it mentions that Probate and Family Court judges have broad discretion in divorce matters, that statement is about securing financial obligations, not scheduling parenting time for educational stability, so the case does not support the specific proposition claimed.
Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182, 191.relevant_excerpt: “A Probate and Family Court judge has ‘broad discretion to fashion judgments in divorce proceedings that will best protect the interests and welfare of the parties’ minor children.’ Pare v. Pare, 409 Mass. 292, 298-299 (1991). The exact form of the order (or the decision to enter an order at all) is also within the judge’s broad discretion. Id. at 300.”

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. at 404.raw_text: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. at 404.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. at 404.proposition: The Court has broad discretion to adjust parenting‑time schedules, including weekday and school‑night overnights, to protect a child’s educational needs and stability.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. at 404.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses custody and visitation generally under the “best interests of the child” standard and affirms the trial judge’s reduction of the father’s visitation time, but it does not address detailed parenting‑time scheduling issues such as weekday or school‑night overnights, nor does it specifically ground visitation changes in protecting educational needs or school stability. The case stands for broad discretion to limit visitation in high‑conflict situations, not for a specific authority to adjust school‑night schedules for educational stability. Thus it is too general and indirect to support the precise proposition claimed.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. at 404.relevant_excerpt: “We pause merely to touch upon the husband’s claim that the judge ‘cut back so severely on the amount of time that [he] may spend with his children that it now is impossible for him to maintain a meaningful relationship with them.’ There is no error. From our above discussion of the record, it should be readily apparent that in view of the circumstances and the personalities involved the judge was justified in reducing the husband’s visitation to less than it previously had been under the temporary custody order… ‘the “best interests” of the child[ren] are to be promoted….’”

In determining the best interests of a c.raw_text: In determining the best interests of a child, the Court may consider the child’s educational needs, attendance, school performance, and each parent’s willingness and ability to meet those needs.
In determining the best interests of a c.proposition: In determining the best interests of a child, the Court may consider the child’s educational needs, attendance, school performance, and each parent’s willingness and ability to meet those needs.

Custody of a Minor, 383 Mass. 595, 602\u.proposition: In determining the best interests of a child, the Court may consider the child’s educational needs, attendance, school performance, and each parent’s willingness and ability to meet those needs.
Custody of a Minor, 383 Mass. 595, 602\u.support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on parental unfitness and psychological harm in a care and protection context, and on the weight to give a mature child’s custodial preferences. While it briefly notes that psychological differences had prevented the child from receiving “educational development,” it does not discuss school attendance, performance, or compare each parent’s willingness and ability to meet educational needs as part of a best-interests analysis. The holding is about unfitness and psychological welfare, not specifically about evaluating educational factors in custody decisions.
Custody of a Minor, 383 Mass. 595, 602\u.relevant_excerpt: “(6) That these differences have prevented [Dom] from receiving sound and normal physical, mental, moral and educational development. (7) The passage of time has created a psychological bond between Dom and his foster parents and in which he has nurtured and developed. (8) To remove him from his foster parents at this time would have serious deleterious effects on Dom.”

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. at 844\u20134.proposition: In determining the best interests of a child, the Court may consider the child’s educational needs, attendance, school performance, and each parent’s willingness and ability to meet those needs.

A parent\u2019s pattern of disregarding.raw_text: A parent’s pattern of disregarding school requirements, failing to support necessary educational interventions, or creating truancy risks may weigh against that parent in allocating legal‑custody authority or school‑night parenting time.
A parent\u2019s pattern of disregarding.proposition: A parent’s pattern of disregarding school requirements, failing to support necessary educational interventions, or creating truancy risks may weigh against that parent in allocating legal‑custody authority or school‑night parenting time.

Abbott v. Virusso, 68 Mass. App. Ct. at.raw_text: Abbott v. Virusso, 68 Mass. App. Ct. at 332–33
Abbott v. Virusso, 68 Mass. App. Ct. at.proposition: A parent’s pattern of disregarding school requirements, failing to support necessary educational interventions, or creating truancy risks may weigh against that parent in allocating legal‑custody authority or school‑night parenting time.

Cooper v. Cooper, 99 Mass. App. Ct. 168,.raw_text: Cooper v. Cooper, 99 Mass. App. Ct. 168, 174–75 (2021)
Cooper v. Cooper, 99 Mass. App. Ct. 168,.proposition: A parent’s pattern of disregarding school requirements, failing to support necessary educational interventions, or creating truancy risks may weigh against that parent in allocating legal‑custody authority or school‑night parenting time.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7\u00a7 10, 20.proposition: To the extent the Court deems this matter within G.L. c. 209C, the same best‑interests and material‑change standards apply.

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 595\u2.proposition: To the extent the Court deems this matter within G.L. c. 209C, the same best‑interests and material‑change standards apply.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 595\u2.support_reasoning: The opinion is a custody dispute arising in the context of a G.L. c. 209C paternity/custody action, but the quoted portion does not articulate or apply any rule that the same best‑interests and material‑change standards apply under c. 209C. The Court focuses on the need for explicit findings regarding domestic violence and references G.L. c. 208, § 31 for shared custody, and explicitly declines to reach several c. 209C arguments in a footnote. Thus, it does not provide authority for the specific proposition stated.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590, 595\u2.relevant_excerpt: "The mother makes a number of claims that we need not address in detail: that the order of joint custody was not in accord with the third paragraph of G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a) (1994 ed.); ... We conclude that the other claims are either subsidiary to the issue we proceed to determine or that the Probate Court judge’s disposition of them was in accordance with law and not an abuse of discretion."

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7\u00a7 28, 31.proposition: Either or both of these modifications—granting the Plaintiff final say on educational decisions and/or reducing the Defendant’s school‑night overnights—are consistent with G.L. c. 208, §§ 28, 31, G.L. c. 209C, § 20, and the case law cited herein and are squarely in Emily’s best interests.
